results.title: Anna (Arabic Version)
results.brief_description: Anna is the story of a young mother and her mentally handicapped son Tom. The film traces the path followed by Anna in overcoming her distrust of professional health workers and outsiders. We follow Anna as she searches with increasing confidence for the extra help that she is told is available to herself and young son Tom.

results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Steve Morrison and Roland Joffe
results.brief_description: Case study of an autistic child growing to adulthood. Both the child and the family discuss autism, giving insights into their feelings and experiences.

results.title: Ankur = The Seedling
results.creator_credit: Blaze Film Enterprises, Mohan Bijlani, Freni Variava and Shyam Benegal
results.brief_description:
Benegal’s first feature, based on his own story, is a subtlely nuanced exploration of the interrelationship between power, ritual, sexuality and violence. The milieu of feudal society in South India is carefully established as the setting for the playing out of power relations in the liaison between the temporarily abandoned wife of a deaf-mute farmhand and the landlord’s son sent to manage the farm. For the son, sexual attraction is linked to the woman’s lack of social status. Yet he is initially restrained by his middle class fear of exposure. From a position of relative anonymity the woman develops a complex response to the son’s presumption.

Credits: Producers, Mohan J. Bijlani, Freni M. Variava ; director, writer, Shyam Benegal ; photography, Govind Nihalani ; music, Vanraj Bhatia.
Cast: Shabana Azmi, Sadhu Meher, Anant Nag, Priya Tendulkar.

results.title: Ankali means friend
results.brief_description: Ankali is part of Sydney’s Albion Street AIDS Centre. It is run by professional staff and 145 volunteer counsellors. The Ankali project has, since 1985, offered emotional support to people with AIDS. This film focuses on two volunteer counsellors, a psychologist and a teacher, and their clients.

results.title: Anish Kapoor [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. This profile of sculptor Anish Kapoor focuses on his extraordinary sculpture ‘Marsyas’ completed in October 2002. Installed in the Turbine Hall at Tate Modern, London, ‘Marsyas’ is a challenging and overwhelming artwork, a vast red PVC membrane stretched between three massive steel rings. This film follows the making of the work, from the earliest maquettes to the complex installation at Tate. Kapoor comments on each stage of the process, and on the ideas and concerns of his art. Also illustrated are a range of his other sculptures including two recent large-scale works: ‘Sky Mirror’ and ‘Taratantara’.

results.title: Animations in the studio
results.creator_credit: Centre for Educational Television Overseas and Lawrie Lawler
results.brief_description: Examines the construction lighting and use of a simple slide animation which allows a sequence of words or symbols to be revealed on the screen at exactly the right moment. Also demonstrates moire fringes, the use of magnets and complicated cardboard animations.

results.title: Animation: a living art form
results.brief_description: Uses the 1971 motion picture “Shinbone Alley” to show the development of an animated film from the script through the storyboard and animation to the final print. No other credits available.

results.title: Animation pie
results.brief_description: A group of high school students go through the processes and experiences of making several animated films. Covers the techniques of flip books, drawing on film, pixilation, cut-outs and clay animation.

results.title: Animation on film
results.brief_description: An introduction to the principles and techniques of film animation, the equipment needed - the rostrum, animation bench, and mounting of the camera are discussed. The planning of animation, and the care and accuracy needed throughout all stages are shown in detail. Roland Kemp is animation advisor.

results.title: Animation on 4. Vol. 02
results.brief_description: A compilation of award-winning animated short films commissioned by Channel 4 in Britain. “Screen play” (dir. Barry Purves) is a tale of doomed love played out on a model Japanese stage. “Abductress” (dir. Paul Vester) combines live action, grainy black and white documentary footage and drawn animation to explore the memories of people who claim to have been abducted by aliens. “The Village” (dir. Mark Baker) juxtaposes delightful storybook images of a traditional village with adult concerns about social behaviour. In “The Sound of music” (dir. Phil Mulloy) uncompromising black ink drawings flesh out an acerbic satire on modern city life. The relationship between rhythm and movement is explored through a seamless merging of the human form with music in “Triangle” (dir. Erica Russell). In “The Mill” (dir. Petra Freeman) a little girl is left to her own devices in an unwelcoming factory. “Secret joy of falling angels’ (dir. Simon Pummell) uses a sumptuous visual feast of mixed media - line drawings, still paintings and model work - to create a seductive, atmospheric abstraction. There is no explicit narrative, instead emotion and instinct guide the viewer through the film’s hypnotic, intertwined threads.
